text: [Music]
alright here's the kitchen conundrum
that I know a lot of people have
poaching eggs it's something that's very
intimidating but actually really simple
to do you just need to know the tricks
most people your eggs turn out like this
that the egg white is kind of splayed
and thin has all of those wispy strands
to it but I'm gonna show you how to
poach a perfect perfectly round egg just
like this and it's very simple to do let
me get started so the most important
thing is using farm-fresh eggs the
fresher the egg at the better and I'm
going to show you why one egg and I like
to crack it into one of these mesh
trainers here and what that does is it
separates the white there are two
components in the egg white there's a
thick white and there's a thin white
what this does is it strains away the
thin white and this is what you want to
discard because this creates those wispy
strands of white when you poach your egg
in addition to the whites there's the
egg yolk which we all know and then a
little membrane called the shell Jose
which is a membrane that connects the
white and the yolk so I'm just going to
gently pour this into a bowl and you can
see I'm ready to poach so now I have a
pot of simmering water you want water
that's just under boiling point about
180 to 190 degrees that's a good
temperature for poaching eggs and into
the water I'm going to add a little bit
of salt and what salt does is it
increases the density of the water and
really helps the egg float off of the
bottom which is what you want you don't
want the eggs sitting on the bottom and
a tablespoon tablespoon and a half of a
white vinegar a neutral vinegar nothing
that has a lot of flavor and I'm going
to give it a little bit of a stir just
so that the salt dissolves and creating
a whirlpool you want a vortex because
you're going to drop your egg right into
the center of the vortex and what that
does is it brings the whites up over the
egg yolk and kind of encases the egg
yolk and that gives you a really nice
shape again the salt what it does is it
creates little bubbles in the water
around the egg white and
it's gonna help to kind of levitate it
off the bottom which helps the egg to
cook at an even rate and you can see the
white just kind of wrapped up over the
yolk there's hardly any wispy strands of
egg white and that's because we strained
it out using the strainer so it's been
about a minute a minute and a half
depending on the size of the egg it will
take between a minute and two minutes
and you can see that the white is just
set and the yolk is still soft so this
is perfect ready to go what I like to do
when I'm making a big brunch when I'm
doing a big breakfast I love to poach
eggs and then place them in a bowl of
ice water and it stops the cooking
process and you can do this in advance
in a big batch and then just heat them
gently right before serving in the same
pot of water but I'm gonna serve this
one up and I like to just rest it on a
towel something to absorb any excess
moisture and you could if you'd like you
can trim away any wispy strands and I
like to serve this on toast of course
you could use an English muffin if
you're gonna do a hollandaise sauce that
would be great and there you have it
perfectly poached eggs if you have any
kitchen conundrums that you need salt
write in the comment section below or
reach out to me using the hashtag

whatever problems you may have
